_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Bongards Creameries 110 3rd Avenue NE, Perham MN is complying with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (PSM), Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119 and EPA' Risk Management Program (RMP) Title 40 CFR Part 68 to deal with the risks involved with the storage, handling and processing of extremely hazardous substances. We do this to promote plant, worker and public safety. 

These programs enable our facility to prevent the occurrence and minimize the consequences of significant releases of toxic substances as well as fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents. Combined, these programs prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and avoid physical property damage. 

FACILITY DESCRIPTION

Bongards' Creameries Perham is a 10 acre Cheese and Whey production facility located within the Perham city limits. Industrial activities include the intake of 4.2 million pounds of milk per day for the purpose of cheese production. The whey from the cheese production is processed and dried on site. There are warehouses on site for the storage of the cheese and whey production.

ANHYDROUS AMMONIA USE 

The process covered by the Bongards' PSM/RMP programs is the ammonia refrigeration system.   Anhydrous ammonia. 18,287 lbs, is utilized in the refrigeration system.  The refrigeration system provides cooling for food processing and storage operations at the facility.  The refrigeration process involves a typical vapor compression refrigeration cycle with compressors, condensers, chillers and evaporators.  The system is closed and is designed to completely contain the ammonia refrigerant within vessels, equipment and piping specifically constructed for ammonia refrigeration.  Liquid ammonia is circulated from the vessels to the evaporators and chillers which cool the process and the refrigerated spaces by boiling off some of the liquid to vapor.  The ammonia then returns to the

vessels where liquid is separated from vapor.  The vapor enters the compressors and is discharged at higher pressure to the condensers.  The vapor is cooled and condenses to liquid in the condenser and then drained to the vessels to repeat the refrigeration cycle.

Our safety programs are applied to activities involving hazardous chemicals including use, storage, manufacturing, handling, or on-site movement of these chemicals. Any group of vessels, which are interconnected, and separate vessels, which are located such that a hazardous chemical could be involved in a potential release, shall be considered a single process. 

Our safety programs prevent accidents because they focus on the rules of 29 CFR 1910.119, procedures and practices, which govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment. These rules are detailed and improved as necessary. They are also communicated to and acknowledged by all employees at the facility. 

Failure of the vertical recirculator containing is limited to 3481 pounds of ammonia at 80% full by facility procedures could result in a 10 minute release of ammonia. 

This scenario is unlikely for the following reasons:
	Worst-case weather conditions are uncommon
	Industry standards for the vessel manufacture and quality control
	Ammonia is not corrosive in this application
	Pressure safety valves protecting this vessel are installed
	Accident prevention and mechanical integrity programs are in place
	Inspection, testing and replacement programs are in place;	
        Trained operators monitor the system regularly
	Log sheets are completed and maintained as a means to detect problems before they get to dangerous levels
	Ammonia sensors are in place to warn of leaks immediately
	An emergency action plan and equipment are in place at the plant

Other release scenarios such as a transfer hose rupturing or a flange leaking could result in a release of ammonia in 60 minutes. 

The transfer hose rupture scenario was chosen as an alt

ernative release because it is a temporary connection and uses materials other than steel. This scenario is unlikely because:
	A monitored switch on the truck could stop flow immediately
	Valves can isolate the hose at each end 
	Plant accident prevention programs are in place including detailed operating procedures
	Personnel are trained to be present at all times during transfer of ammonia
	Accident prevention and mechanical integrity programs are in place
	Inspection, testing and replacement programs are in place
	An emergency action plan is in place at the plant

UPDATE FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 

In the past 5 years there has been one release at this facility. 
The facility's emergency response program is based on the OSHA requirements for Emergency Action Plans (29 CFR 1910.38 and 1910.119. We have trained employees for emergency action and maintain a written emergency action plan. This plan is coordinated with local officials and safety personnel. We conduct annual drills for implementation of the emergency action plan at the facility. We train with the participation of local responders. Parts of our plan include:

1.	Notification of management and maintenance of a release
2.	Determination of what, and where the release is coming from 
3.	Concentration of chemical in air is determined to assess action plan
4.	Determine plan of action
5.	Isolate leaking equipment
6.	Fans are available for air movement and dissipation
7.	Repair broken equipment
8.	Water hose to knock down fumes 
9.	Respirators are available to protect action personnel
10.	Drain barriers are available to prevent chemicals from entering storm drains
11.	Intercom for notification of personnel for evacuation
12.	Fire Department and Emergency Action team phone numbers are posted for quick notification if necessary.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

As a Program 3 stationary source, we certified that no additional measures are necessary to prevent offsite impacts from accidental releases.  We are

developing recommendations as a result of equipment inspections, safety meetings, review of industry experience, technology improvements, and employee suggestions.  It is the intent of Bongards Creameries Perham to follow the programs set out in the Process Safety Management program to ensure the safety and health of the personnel employed, citizens and environment of the area around the our facility.
